p: Several human diseases, including PD, are associated with protein misfolding and aggregation [ 70]. aSyn, a key player in PD, is a long-lived protein and, therefore, is likely to be glycated over time [ 71]. In fact, AGEs colocalize with aSyn in Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra [ 72, 73], and we have recently identified glycated aSyn in brain tissue from PD patients [ 74]. Furthermore, it was shown that aSyn can be glycated in vitro, in the N-terminal region, by dicarbonyl compounds and ribose [ 74â€“76].
